lawSummary: US lease law is primarily governed by state law, with federal protections under the Fair Housing Act and Americans with Disabilities Act. Common law principles and state-specific landlord-tenant statutes apply. Key protections include habitability requirements, anti-discrimination laws, and procedural requirements for eviction.

requiredClauses.title: Termination and Eviction
requiredClauses.legalBasis: State Landlord-Tenant Acts, Fair Housing Act
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Must follow state-specific notice requirements (typically 3-30 days). Cannot include self-help eviction. Must provide proper notice and court process.

requiredClauses.title: Security Deposit
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Follow state limits (typically 1-2 months rent). Provide itemized deductions within state timeline (usually 14-30 days). Include interest requirements if applicable.

requiredClauses.title: Habitability and Repairs
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Landlord must maintain habitability. Cannot waive landlord's repair obligations. Specify tenant's limited repair responsibilities.

requiredClauses.title: Rent Payment
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Late fees must be reasonable (typically 5-10% of rent). Include grace period. Accept multiple payment methods.

requiredClauses.title: Fair Housing Compliance
requiredClauses.legalBasis: Fair Housing Act, Americans with Disabilities Act
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Cannot discriminate based on protected classes. Must allow reasonable accommodations for disabilities. Occupancy limits must be reasonable.

requiredClauses.title: Entry and Privacy
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Specify notice requirements (typically 24-48 hours). Limit entry to reasonable purposes. Respect tenant privacy rights.

requiredClauses.title: Sub-leasing and Assignment
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Cannot unreasonably withhold consent to sub-lease. Include reasonable approval process. Cannot charge excessive fees.

requiredClauses.title: Utilities and Services
requiredClauses.draftingHints: Clearly specify utility responsibilities. Cannot charge excessive fees. Include service standards and complaint procedures.
